Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: An HOA inspection is scheduled and items left in the corridor could be cited for blocking an emergency exit.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: I was counting the register at the end of my shift, my mind half on the stack of twenties in my hand and half on the text from my neighbor, Mrs. Lee. She’d left her old stroller and a couple of boxes in the corridor again, right outside my apartment. The HOA inspection was tomorrow, and I knew anything left out could get us both fined. As her neighbor, I wanted to be considerate, maybe help her move the stuff or at least remind her gently. But as a cashier, I was expected to focus—especially now, with the safe open and the numbers needing to match exactly. My manager had warned us: one mistake, and the whole drawer would be off. I could feel the pressure building, my phone buzzing with another message from Mrs. Lee, while the register beeped impatiently for my attention. I stood there, torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, knowing I couldn’t do both at once.
